title: R44325
content: The level of pay for congressional staff is determined by Senate committees, with job titles, pay rates, and resources set by the chair and ranking Member. Congressional pay data is sought for various reasons, such as assessing costs, setting pay levels, and comparing with other federal government systems. Aggregated congressional staff pay data is not readily available, but this report uses official Senate reports for consistent data collection. The pay data for congressional staff is based on official Senate reports, published semiannually, and collected by LegiStorm. This report provides annual data by fiscal year for 13 staff position titles used in Senate committees since FY2001. The report provides pay data for 13 staff position titles used in Senate committees since FY2001. Position titles were identified through a two-step process, with 13 positions having sufficient data available for analysis. Pay data for 13 staff positions in Senate committees since FY2001 were collected, excluding titles used by six or fewer panels. Data needed to be available from at least five committees for each position. Only up to two staff per committee with the same job title were included, and staff had to hold the position for the entire fiscal year without pay from other congressional authorities. The collected data may include overtime, bonuses, or other payments in addition to base salary. LegiStorm data tabulates staff pay for the fiscal year, including overtime, bonuses, and other payments in addition to base salary. Pay data for staff in House committee offices can be found in CRS Report R44322, while data for congressional staff in personal offices are available in CRS Report R44324 and CRS Report R44323. The data presented may have challenges that could impact findings or interpretation. Data presented here for selected positions in House Member Offices from 2001-2014 may not fully represent all Senate committee staff jobs due to the large number of positions held by one employee. Two categories of positions emerge, with the first category likely providing highly representative pay information for staff in those roles. The second category includes positions where committees may hire multiple staff members. The pay data collected for Senate committee staff positions may not fully represent all staff jobs due to the variety of positions held by one employee. Two categories of positions are identified, with the first category likely providing more representative pay information. The second category includes positions where committees may hire multiple staff members, resulting in a sample of staff rather than complete data. Pay data does not consider factors like education, work experience, or job duties, and assumes staff with the same title perform similar tasks. The pay data for Senate committee staff positions may not fully represent all staff jobs due to differences in job duties and levels of compensation. Congressional employing authorities have wide discretion in setting terms of employment, leading to potential differences in duties for similarly titled staff. Tables in this section provide background information on Senate pay practices and detailed data for each position. Tables in this section provide background information on Senate pay practices, comparative data for each position, and detailed data and visualizations. Table 2 shows maximum payable rates for Senate committee staff since 2001 in nominal and constant 2016 dollars. Table 3 displays cumulative percentage changes in median pay for different positions. Tables 4 to 16 provide tabular pay data for each Senate committee staff position, with graphic displays included for additional perspectives. Between FY2011 and FY2015, median pay for Senate committee staff positions changed, ranging from a 16.93% increase for professional staff members to a -16.48% decrease. Graphic displays show pay data comparisons over different time intervals and distributions of pay in 2016 dollars. Between FY2011 and FY2015, median pay for Senate committee staff positions changed, with some positions seeing pay increases while others saw declines. Comparisons to the pay of Members of Congress and General Schedule in Washington, DC show varying trends in pay changes over the same period. Additionally, between FY2006 and FY2015, there were fluctuations in median pay for different staff positions, with some experiencing increases and others facing declines. Between FY2001 and FY2015, median pay for various staff positions showed fluctuations, with some positions experiencing pay increases while others saw declines. For example, senior counsels had a 22.01% increase, while staff assistants had a -26.72% decrease in pay. Comparisons to Members of Congress and General Schedule in Washington, DC also showed varying trends in pay changes over the same period.
